event: the Myanmar campaign of the Qing dynasty
Burmese_name: တရုတ်-မြန်မာ စစ်ပွဲများ
description: A military conflict fought between the Qing dynasty of China and the Konbaung dynasty of Burma, considered one of Qianlong Emperor's Ten Great Campaigns.

implications: Solidified tripartite division of Mainland Southeast Asia between Burma, Siam, and Vietnam
Resumption of diplomatic relations between Burma and Qing Empire in 1790

campaign_overview.initial_perception: Qing emperor envisaged an easy war, sending only the Green Standard Army troops stationed in Yunnan.
turning_points: Third invasion nearly succeeded, reaching central Burma close to Ava.
Fourth invasion bogged down at the frontier with Qing forces encircled.

post_war_situation.Qing_military_presence: Kept a heavy military lineup in the border areas of Yunnan for about one decade.
post_war_situation.Burma_military_preparation: Kept a series of garrisons along the border, preoccupied with the Chinese threat.
post_war_situation.diplomatic_relations: Resumed in 1790 with the Qing unilaterally viewing it as Burmese submission and claiming victory.

long_term_effects.Siamese_recovery: Siamese reclaimed most of their territories in the next three years after having lost their capital Ayutthaya to the Burmese in 1767.

references.source: History of Civilizations of Central Asia: Development in Contrast: From the Sixteenth to the Mid-Nineteenth Century. UNESCO. 2003
Peter C. Perdue, China Marches West: The Qing Conquest of Central Asia
Christian Tyler, Wild West China: The Taming of Xinjiang
